column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.RoleAnnotation|roles
#Text=Mr.
#Text=Zidar (Slovenia): I would like to thank\r
#Text=Uganda for the initiative to convene this important\r
#Text=open debate on women, peace and security.
#Text=I also thank\r
#Text=the Secretary-General, Under-Secretary-General for\r
#Text=Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women\r
#Text=Bachelet and other distinguished guests for their\r
#Text=presentations today.
#Text=Slovenia fully aligns itself with the statements to\r
#Text=be delivered by the representative of the European\r
#Text=Union and by the representative of Costa Rica on\r
#Text=behalf of the Human Security Network.
#Text=Resolution 1325 (2000) on women, peace and\r
#Text=security acknowledged that women are not just victims\r
#Text=of armed conflict and that their equal and full\r
#Text=participation is of vital importance in conflict\r
#Text=prevention, peacekeeping, conflict resolution,\r
#Text=peacebuilding and post-conflict recovery.
#Text=In the past 10 years, many activities have been\r
#Text=carried out to strengthen the role of women during and\r
#Text=after conflict.
#Text=However, this anniversary reminds us\r
#Text=that despite those efforts, much needs to be done in the\r
#Text=protection of women and in the promotion of the\r
#Text=participation of women at the decision-making level, in\r
#Text=conflict resolution and in peace processes.
#Text=Violence against women, especially sexual and\r
#Text=gender-based violence, persists in conflicts.
#Text=Recent\r
#Text=events in the Democratic Republic of the Congo have\r
#Text=shown that women continue to be deliberate targets of\r
#Text=injustice and sexual violence in the conflict and its\r
#Text=aftermath.
#Text=In his report (S/2010/498), the Secretary-General\r
#Text=takes up United Nations activities in the\r
#Text=implementation of resolution 1325 (2000).
#Text=The report\r
#Text=shows that a vast range of activities has been carried\r
#Text=out in the past 10 years.
#Text=However, the fragmentation of\r
#Text=those activities demonstrates the need to streamline and\r
#Text=coordinate the action of all members of the\r
#Text=international community.
#Text=Slovenia supports the\r
#Text=Secretary-General's recommendation to develop a\r
#Text=single comprehensive framework that consists of an\r
#Text=agreed set of goals, targets and indicators to guide the\r
#Text=implementation of the resolution in its second decade.
#Text=We are of the opinion that the issue of women,\r
#Text=peace and security needs to be addressed in a holistic\r
#Text=and comprehensive manner.
#Text=We welcome the Security\r
#Text=Council's decision to take forward the set of indicators\r
#Text=developed by the Secretary-General to track the\r
#Text=implementation of resolution 1325 (2000) in situations\r
#Text=of armed conflict as well as post-conflict and other\r
#Text=situations.
#Text=We hope that the indicators will now\r
#Text=become operational.
#Text=Slovenia also supports the recommendation to\r
#Text=establish a dedicated working group to review progress\r
#Text=in the implementation of resolution 1325 (2000) and to\r
#Text=make recommendations to the Security Council on how\r
#Text=to address gaps and challenges to accelerate progress in\r
#Text=the implementation of the resolution.
#Text=Stronger steps should be taken to address\r
#Text=accountability and to end impunity for perpetrators of\r
#Text=violations.
#Text=The Security Council should impose\r
#Text=targeted and graduated measures against all parties to a\r
#Text=conflict responsible for grave violations of women's\r
#Text=rights, including sexual violence.
#Text=Sexual violence\r
#Text=should be a priority element in all Council resolutions\r
#Text=mandating the sanctions committees.
#Text=We all have a responsibility to implement\r
#Text=resolution 1325 (2000).
#Text=The development of national\r
#Text=action plans is a key means by which Member States\r
#Text=commit themselves to fulfilling that responsibility.
#Text=I\r
#Text=would like to report that Slovenia is about to finalize\r
#Text=and adopt such an action plan.
#Text=The goal is to\r
#Text=interconnect existing national and international\r
#Text=activities addressing a broader concept of women,\r
#Text=peace and security in order to translate them into\r
#Text=genuine political commitments, and thus accelerate the\r
#Text=implementation of resolution 1325 (2000) and\r
#Text=contribute to the empowerment and protection of\r
#Text=women.
#Text=In Slovenia, gender equality is a priority not only\r
#Text=in the field of human rights and development\r
#Text=cooperation but also in security and defence policy.
#Text=Since 2008, much has been done to promote gender\r
#Text=equality in the security and defence sector.
#Text=Those\r
#Text=activities range from awareness-raising and training to\r
#Text=the adoption and modification of legislation and other\r
#Text=measures, including codes of conduct.
#Text=The recently\r
#Text=adopted strategy on the participation of the Republic of\r
#Text=Slovenia in international operations and missions\r
#Text=promotes equal opportunities with regard to such\r
#Text=efforts at all levels, irrespective of gender.
#Text=Lastly, let me take this opportunity to encourage\r
#Text=the Security Council to continue to address the issue of\r
#Text=women, peace and security and to seek the most\r
#Text=effective means to improve the situation of women in\r
#Text=armed conflict.
#Text=With a comprehensive United Nations\r
#Text=approach and increased ownership by Member States\r
#Text=over their activities, the plight of women in situations\r
#Text=of armed conflict and its aftermath can be eliminated.
